According to Singh, Che's "charismatic presence in green olive fatigues and black beret" at the time embodied "the very best of the Hollywood and Bollywood stars all rolled into one"<ref>[http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=9324 A Meeting with Che Guevara] by K Gajendra Singh, Global Research, June 14, 2008</ref> Even under duress, ''[[The Times]]'' journalist Henry Brandon, who spoke with Guevara at the height of the [[Cuban missile crisis]], remarked that Che possessed a "genial charm" that "might have made [[Charles Boyer]] envious."<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article5062895.ece From the archive: Attack us at your peril, cocky Cuba warns US] ''Times'' Online, November 2, 2008</ref>
In judging the enduring appeal of the image, Darrel Couturier, representative for Korda since 1997, has opined that it was "the image of a very dashing young man" and that in the "age of free love and flower power … the time was ripe for a figure" or "image that could represent this great diversity in thinking and behavior the world over." According to Couturier, this "age of religious revolution", matched with Guevara's premature death, "elevated him to almost [[martyrdom]]."<ref>[http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/detaylar.do?load=detay&link=156339 ‘Korda’s Che from Revolution to Icon’ travels to İstanbul] by Rumeysa Kiger, ''Today's Zaman'', October 20, 2008</ref>
== Influence on art and culture == {{Main|Che Guevara in popular culture}}
[[File:WarholChe.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Gerard Malanga]]'s 1968 [[Andy Warhol]] forgery of Che Guevara.]]
{{quotation|"When you look closely, you can see that many iconic photographs are constructed in the same way; it is possible to copy the formula. Look at some of the most enduring images of our age … Like Che, they are shot from below against a light background, giving them a raised, Godlike quality. The angle of the shot is particularly crucial, as profiles have little impact and full frontals tend to flatten the features. The direction and intensity of the subject's gaze is also key. Che is looking past the camera, out to his vision. His line of vision has been much tinkered with by various artists, but it retains its passion even on a table mat or a screensaver. An image like this is about a sign: it's a shorthand. This particular one now stands for opposition to the establishment, freedom and revolution."| [[Alison Jackson]], photographer and filmmaker <ref>[http://www.newstatesman.com/print/200606120036 Che: The Artists View] by [[Alison Jackson]], ''[[New Statesman]]'', June 12, 2006</ref>}}
As pop artists took to the image with glee, it evolved into a popular and heavily commercialized icon that often strayed far from Che’s hard-line [[Marxist]] message.<ref name="WSJ2010" /> British [[pop artist]] [[Peter Blake (artist)|Sir Peter Blake]] has referred to ''Guerrillero Heroico'' as "one of the great icons of the 20th century."<ref name="guardian2004">[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/jul/11/features.review Just a Pretty Face?] by Sean O'Hagan, ''The Observer'', July 11, 2004</ref> When converted into a stark black cut-out, Korda's photograph became easy, cheap, and fast to copy using the favored material and method of the 1960s: lith film and screen painting.<ref>"Che Guevara: Revolutionary & Icon", by Trisha Ziff, Abrams Image, 2006, pg 42</ref> By the time of his death in 1967, Che was already "a legend, the romantic epitome of worldwide rebellion" and in the wake of his perceived martyrdom, Korda's photograph went viral.<ref name="Alook">A look at Che Guevara through the Lens of his Iconic Image, by Robert W. Butler, ''[[The Miami Herald]]'', February 19, 2010</ref> Rebellious young people found in it a "sense of empowerment, a crystallization of the perennial idealism of youth."<ref name="Alook" />
[[File:Protest against corruption - Bucharest 2017 - Arcul de Triumf.jpg|thumb|[[2017–2018 Romanian protests|Romanian protests]] against government corruption in 2017]] According to the [[Victoria and Albert Museum|V&A Museum]], "the photograph enshrines Che as a mythic hero. Taken from below, the revolutionary leader with searching eyes and resolute expression becomes larger than life. A perspective that dominates the imagery of social realism, it bears an irresistible aura of authority, independence and defiance."<ref name="va" /> The V&A Museum goes on to state that Korda's famous photograph first [[Apotheosis|deified]] Che and turned him into an [[icon]] of [[radical chic]]. Its story, a complex mesh of conflicting narratives, gave ''Guerrillero Heroico'' a life of its own, an enduring fascination independent of Che himself.<ref name="va" /> The Italian magazine ''Skime'' evokes even more praise, decreeing it "absolutely the most famous of history" while proclaiming that it "captures beauty and youth, courage and generosity, aesthetic and moral virtues of a person who possessed all the characteristics necessary to be converted into a symbol of an [[Epoch (reference date)|epoch]] like ours, lacking in historic legends and mythic incarnations."<ref>"Che Guevara: Revolutionary & Icon", by Trisha Ziff, Abrams Image, 2006, pg 41</ref> Journalist [[Richard Gott]] has also remarked that "the red star in Che's beret was up there with '[[Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds]].{{' "}}<ref name="thehindu2006" /> Jonathan Green, director of the [[University of California Riverside|UCR]] photography museum, has remarked that "pop art is a rejection of traditional figuration, rhetoric, and rendition. Its egalitarian anti-art stance was the perfect corollary for Che's anti-establishment attitude."<ref>"Che Guevara: Revolutionary & Icon", by Trisha Ziff, Abrams Image, 2006, pg 75</ref>
Fitzpatrick's graphic was later used in a 1968 painting attributed to [[Andy Warhol]] and sold to a gallery in Rome. The painting used the same graphic processes used on the acclaimed [[Marilyn Monroe]] pieces. However this painting was a forgery, created by [[Gerard Malanga]] who was in need of money. When Warhol heard of the fraud, he "authenticated" the fake, provided that all the money from sales went to him.<ref>Bourdon, David. ''"Warhol"''. Harry N. Abrams Inc, 1989 pg 291</ref>
=== Exhibits === [[File:CheMosaicInMatanzas.jpg|200px|thumb|right|A public rock mosaic along a street in [[Matanzas, Cuba]].]]
{{quotation|"It is the image of a very dashing young man who was part of a revolution. This was a revolution of the people for the people in a time when there was a great unrest in many parts of the world, particularly in Latin America, Europe and the US. The Vietnam War was raging; students and workers were protesting and striking; it was the age of free love and flower power; it was the pop age; it was the age of religious revolution. The time was ripe for a figure, an image that could represent this great diversity in thinking and behavior the world over. Che's role in the Cuban Revolution made him a revered symbol of world class struggle, equality and freedom from domination and his premature death in 1967 elevated him to almost martyrdom."| Darrel Couturier, Alberto Korda's agent who arranged his first U.S. exhibition in the 1998 <ref name="Zaman" />}} * 1968, the 'Arts Laboratory' in London held an exhibition on the photograph entitled "Viva Che."<ref>[http://www.cmp.ucr.edu/exhibitions/che/essay_002.htm Korda's Che Moves Out into the World] by Trisha Ziff, 2005</ref> * 1990, the Jour Agnes B Gallery in Paris, France, presented an exhibit of Korda's image titled "Che Guevara: A 21st Century Man."<ref>{{cite web|author=Cubarte |url=http://www.galeriacubarte.cult.cu/g_artista.php?item=105&lang=eng |title=Cubarte Gallery: Alberto Korda |publisher=Galeriacubarte.cult.cu |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> * 1998, the [[UCLA]] [[Fowler Museum of Cultural History]] in Los Angeles, California, featured an exhibition compiled by David Kunzle titled "Che Guevara: Icon, Myth and Message."<ref name="kordaporsiempre1">{{cite web|url=http://www.kordaporsiempre.com/curri_2.htm |title=Exposiciones Colectivas (Selección) |publisher=Korda Por Siempre |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> * 2003, the Centre for Contemporary Art in [[Rethymnon]], Greece, presented an exhibit titled "Che Guevara's Death."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.travel-to-crete.com/article.php?article_id=5 |title=35 years without Che Guevara – Photography Exhibition in Rethymnon |publisher=Travel-to-crete.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> * 2004, the Centro Nacional de la Música, in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]], held an exhibition titled "Che Guevara by the photographers of the Cuban Revolution."<ref name="kordaporsiempre1" /> * 2005, the [[University of California, Riverside California Museum of Photography|UCR/California Museum of Photography]] featured an exhibition titled "Revolution and Commerce: The Legacy of Korda's Portrait of Che Guevara."<ref>{{cite web|author=UCR/California Museum of Photography |url=http://www.cmp.ucr.edu/exhibitions/che/ |title=Revolution and Commerce: The Legacy of Korda's Portrait of Che Guevara |publisher=Cmp.ucr.edu |date=1960-03-05 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> * 2005, the [[International Center of Photography]] in New York City held an exhibition titled "¡Che! Revolution and Commerce." * 2006, the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in London hosted an exhibition titled "Che Guevara: Revolutionary and Icon."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/vastatic/microsites/1541_che/ |title=V&A – Che Guevara: Revolutionary & Icon |publisher=Vam.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> * 2007, the La Triennale in [[Milan]], Italy, featured an exhibition titled "Che Guevara Rebel and Icon: The Legacy of Korda's Portrait." * 2007, the [[Tropenmuseum]] in Amsterdam held a special exhibition about the photograph titled "Che! A Commercial Revolution." * 2007, the [[Frost Art Museum]] at [[Florida International University]] in Miami, Florida, presented an exhibition featuring the photograph.<ref>"Meet the Man Behind the Dorm Room Poster", By Raina McLeod, ''Miami New Times'', January 18, 2007</ref> * 2008, the WestLicht Gallery in [[Vienna]], Austria, offered an exhibition on ''Guerrillero Heróico'' in relation to the "development of a mythos."<ref>[http://www.artdaily.com/section/news/index.asp?int_sec=11&int_new=24440&int_modo=1 WestLicht Gallery Reconsiders Che Guevara in Photography Exhibit in Vienna] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221213145/http://www.artdaily.com/section/news/index.asp?int_sec=11&int_new=24440&int_modo=1 |date=2008-12-21 }} from ''Art Daily''</ref> * 2008, the Fototeca center in [[Havana]], Cuba, held an exhibition titled "Korda, Known. Unknown." * 2008, the [[Santralistanbul]] in [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]], hosted the exhibit "Narrative of a Portrait: Korda's Che from Revolution to Icon."<ref name="Zaman">[http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/detaylar.do?load=detay&link=156339 'Korda’s Che from Revolution to Icon' Travels to İstanbul] ''[[Today's Zaman]]'', November 10, 2008</ref> * 2009, the Dom Nashchokina Gallery in Moscow, hosted the exhibition "Che: Hasta Siempre! Meet You in the Eternity" from June 18 to September 20, 2009.<ref>[http://www.russia-ic.com/news/show/8436/#comment_5892 Meet Legendary Che Guevara in Moscow] June 18, 2009</ref> * 2010, the [[International Center of Photography]] in New York City, hosted the exhibition "Cuba in Revolution" from November 11 to January 9, 2011 – which featured several versions of the image.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/12/arts/design/12revolution.html?pagewanted=print Tumult and Triumph in Black and White] by Ken Johnson, ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 11, 2010</ref>
=== Posters and covers === [[File:CheTriContinental.jpg|160px|thumb|left|An [[OSPAAAL]] poster advertising the 1969 [[Tricontinental Conference]].]]
{{Quote box | quote="It is the photograph that adorns student bedsits across the world. The famed black and white portrait of Ernesto "Che" Guevara perfectly captured his intense stare and brooding good looks, helping establish his myth." | source = — ''[[The Guardian]]'' <ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/mar/07/row-iconic-image-che-guevara Row rages over iconic image of Che Guevara] by Jamie Doward, ''[[The Observer]]'', March 7, 2010</ref> | width = 25% | align = right }} * In 1967 Polish artist [[Roman Cieslewicz]] designed a poster with the words "Che Si" (translation: 'Yes Che') emblazoned over his face as eyes and nose. This was later featured on the October 1967 cover of the French art magazine ''Opus International''. * In 1968, Elena Serrano produced a widely distributed poster titled "Day of the Heroic Guerrilla", which shows telescoping images of Korda's photograph expanding to cover the entire red map of South America. * The 1968 February issue of ''[[Evergreen Review]]'', featured Che's image in a painted form by Paul Davis. * The September 1969 issue of ''Tricontinental Magazine'' featured a conjoined image of Korda's Che with [[Ho Chi Minh]]. * During a 1969 student strike at [[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley]], a poster was produced and distributed with a cartoon bubble coming from Che's mouth possessing the words: "Shut it down!" * In 1970, the [[Art Workers' Coalition]] produced a widely distributed [[anti-Vietnam War]] poster featuring an outline of Che on a yellow background, with his famous quotation: "Let me say at the risk of appearing ridiculous, that the true revolutionary is guided by great feelings of love." * The [[Rage Against The Machine]] artwork for their 1993 single, "[[Bombtrack]]" features a mirrored version of the iconic two-tone portrait by Jim Fitzpatrick. * The September 16, 1996 edition of ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' magazine titled: "The Myth of Che Guevara", featured Che's image adorned with a [[Halo (religious iconography)|halo]] of moving bullets. * A computerized rendition of ''Guerrillero Heroico'' appeared on the cover of the March 1–7, 2006 issue of ''[[Metro Silicon Valley|Metro]]'', above the title "The Blog Revolution." * In 2003, [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s album ''[[American Life]]'' featured the singer redoing ''Guerrillero Heroico''. * The December 2008 issue of ''[[Rolling Stone]] Argentina'' features ''Guerrillero Heroico'' on the cover.<ref>{{cite magazine |date=December 2008 |title=[Cover] |magazine=Rolling Stone Magazine (Argentine edition) |page=cover}}</ref>
== Commodity == [[File:CheShirtsMuseum.jpg|220px|thumb|right|upright|T-shirts for sale at the [[Museum of the Revolution (Cuba)|Museo de la Revolución]] gift shop in [[Havana, Cuba]].]] {{See also|Che Guevara clothing and fashion accessories}} The Che image has been cited as an example of the merging of politics and marketing and the power that images hold over our society.<ref name="WSJ2010" /> Trisha Ziff, the curator of a 2004 touring exhibition on the [[iconography]] of Che has stated that "Che Guevara has become a brand. And the brand's logo is the image, which represents change. It has become the icon of the outside thinker, at whatever level, whether it is anti-war, pro-green or anti-globalisation. Its presence, everywhere from Belfast to Soweto, or from walls in the Palestinian territories to Parisian boutiques, makes it an image that is out of control. It has become a corporation, an empire, at this point."<ref name="stephanie2007">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7028598.stm Che: The icon and the ad] by Stephanie Holmes, October 5, 2007, ''BBC''.</ref>
Alberto Korda's photograph has received wide distribution and modification, appearing on countless numbers of T-shirts, posters, consumer products, protest banners, personal tattoos, and in many other formats. It has morphed into an iconic [[counterculture|countercultural]] symbol for a new generation of youth.<ref>[http://www.newstatesman.com/travel/2008/06/argentina-guevara-bronze Guevara's Last Stand] by Chris Bradley, ''New Statesman'', June 12, 2008</ref> The image is now worn on the chests of a diverse group of individuals, from those who truly support the ideals that Che Guevara lived for, to those expressing a more generalized anti-authoritarian stance.<ref name="stephanie2007" />
== Iconography == [[File:Che Mural7.jpg|200px|thumb|left|A mural of ''Guerrillero Heroico'' on the side of a house in Cuba.]]
{{quote|If this were a photo session, you couldn't have asked for more. The model, long-haired with steely gaze and wispy guerrillero beard. Jacket zipped to the chin. Collar up and hair uncombed. Jaw set in anger. Beret at a perfect, rakish tilt. There's tension even in his pose: his shoulders turning one way, his face another. And those eyes, mournful but defiant, staring up and to the right as if at some distant vision of the future, or a giant, slow-approaching foe.| [[Ben Ehrenreich]], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' <ref>[http://www.latimes.com/features/lifestyle/la-ig-che1-2008jun01,0,2014456.story Capitalizing on Che Guevara's image] by [[Ben Ehrenreich]], the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', June 1, 2008</ref>}}
Journalist Michael Casey, in his 2009 book ''Che's Afterlife: The Legacy of an Image'', notes how the universal image can be found "in all corners of the world" and theorizes that it arrived as a symbol of rebellion during an era when the world was aching for change.<ref name="CNNCasey" /> In defining Korda's photograph as a "brand" and "quintessential post-modern icon", Casey notes that somehow the photograph encapsulates "hope and beauty," which causes people around the globe to "invest their dreams in it."<ref name="CNNCasey" /> While David Kunzle, author of the book ''Che Guevara: Icon, Myth, and Message'', has opined that "The [[beret]] functions subliminally as a flattened [[Halo (religious iconography)|halo]]."<ref>"Che Guevara: Revolutionary & Icon", by Trisha Ziff, Abrams Image, 2006, pg 88</ref>
[[File:Sfikasaragod.jpg|thumb|A Che banner in [[Kasargod]], [[India]], announcing the district conference for the [[Students Federation of India]].]]
Trisha Ziff, the curator of ''Che! Revolution and Commerce'' describes ''Guerrillero Heroico'' as a "statuesque image taken from below," which "derives from a visual language of mythologized heroes harking back to an era of socialist realism" while referencing "a classical Christ-like demeanor."<ref>[http://www.cmp.ucr.edu/exhibitions/che/essay_001.htm Korda's Che Moves Out into the World] by Trisha Ziff, UCR exhibit introduction</ref> [[Jon Lee Anderson]], author of ''Che Guevara: A Revolutionary Life'', in the photograph Che appears "as the ultimate revolutionary icon" with "his eyes staring boldly into the future" and "his expression a virile embodiment of outrage at social injustice."<ref name="guardian2004" />
The stylized image of Che Guevara, adapted from Korda's photograph, is commonly accompanied by several different symbols that add context to its inherent suggested meaning. The most common of these are the [[red star]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.popicontees.com/prodimages/Che/J4-large.jpg |title=Che + red star |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715103751/http://www.popicontees.com/prodimages/Che/J4-large.jpg |archivedate=2011-07-15 |df= }}</ref> [[hammer and sickle]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://inter.kke.gr/PhotoAlbum/diafora/history/inter/che-hammer/ |title=Che + Hammer and Sickle |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721082820/http://inter.kke.gr/PhotoAlbum/diafora/history/inter/che-hammer/ |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref> [[Cuban flag]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/photos/uncategorized/2008/08/15/cubabeisbol.jpg |title=Che + Cuban Flag |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05 |work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> and the saying in Spanish ''"Hasta la Victoria Siempre"''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liorkaridi.com/Travel/Cuba/Camaguey_2.jpg |title=Che Guevara + ''Hasta la Victoria Siempre'' |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> (Translation: "Towards Victory, Always"). The multi meaning phrase became the sign off for Che Guevara's numerous letters and speeches as a revolutionary,<ref>[http://www.codexlagman.com/jpgs/codexlagman_links_02.jpg Che Guevara monument in Santa Clara] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305152404/http://www.codexlagman.com/jpgs/codexlagman_links_02.jpg |date=2009-03-05 }}</ref> and represent the commitment to both never give up on the eventual triumph of a [[Marxist]] [[world revolution]], and the belief that this victory once it occurs, will be [[Permanent revolution|eternal]]. As a result, ''"Hasta la Victoria Siempre"'' has become a de facto [[slogan]] or [[catchphrase]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.guim.co.uk/Guardian/travel/gallery/2008/feb/22/cuba/ChePlazaRev-7640.jpg |title=Plaza of the Revolution in Havana, Cuba |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> used as a [[motto]] by those who continue to support and/or admire Che Guevara's life and/or ideals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://omega.wordpress.com/2007/10/09/remembering-che-hasta-la-victoria-siempre/ |title=Remembering Che: Hasta La Victoria Siempre! |publisher=Omega.wordpress.com |date=2007-10-09 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref>
== Current legal status == [[File:CheBillboardCubanHW.jpg|260px|thumb|right|A 2009 highway billboard with Che's slogan of ''"Hasta la Victoria Siempre"'' (Towards Victory, Always).]]
For decades the famous image was unhindered by [[international copyright agreements]], because Cuba was not a signatory to the [[Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works|Berne Convention]]. [[Fidel Castro]] described it as a "[[bourgeois]] concept" which meant that artists and advertisers were free to use Korda’s work as they pleased.<ref name="WSJ2010">[https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/03/05/che-the-birthday-of-a-revolutionary-brand/ Che: The Birthday of a Revolutionary Brand] by Michael J. Casey, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', March 5, 2010</ref> Legally, Cuban Law no. 156 signed on September 28, 1994, to amend part of Law no. 14 of the 1977 Copyright Act (Article 47), states that pictures taken in Cuba fall into the public domain worldwide, 25 years after their first use.<ref>''WIPO Guide to Intellectual Property Worldwide'', Issue 479 of WIPO publication, by the World Intellectual Property Organization, 2000, {{ISBN|92-805-0856-3}}, pg 144–147</ref> As for the United States, since the image was first published in Cuba without compliance with U.S. [[copyright formalities]] and used in Cuba before February 20, 1972 (more than 25 years before Cuba signed the Berne Convention in 1997) it is also generally, although not universally, considered to be in the [[public domain]].
Despite conflicting claims about whether or not the image could have copyright established, Korda's children have sought to control commercial use of the image from [[defamation]]. Korda's daughter Diana Diaz pursued a 2003 lawsuit in France against a Paris-based press rights group [[Reporters Without Borders]], for using the Che photograph in a poster campaign decrying Cuba as "the world's largest jail", aimed at dissuading French tourists from vacationing in Cuba after the jailing of 29 dissident journalists.<ref name="commondreams2005">Reuters, "[http://www.commondreams.org/cgi-bin/print.cgi?file=/headlines05/0829-01.htm Che's Family Plans to Fight Use of Famed Photo]", ''Common Dreams'', August 29, 2005</ref> In suing the group for 1.14 million [[euros]], Diaz's lawyer, Randy Yaloz remarked that "we are going after everyone who betrays the moral rights of my client".<ref name="CubaN">Korda Daughter Sues RSF Over Image of Che, by ''Cuba News'', March 2004</ref> [[Moral rights (copyright law)|Moral rights]] are a separate component of [[copyright law]] that are not recognized in the U.S., but are recognized in some other countries, notably in France where Diaz filed the lawsuit.<ref name="Vaver">''Intellectual Property Rights: Critical Concepts in Law'', Volume 2, by D. Vaver, Taylor & Francis, 2006, {{ISBN|0-415-33089-0}}, pg 273–280</ref> Moral rights aim to protect the integrity of a work from defamation, distortion, slander, or offensive mutilation, even if the originator no longer owns the copyright.<ref name="Vaver" /> However, Reporters Without Borders stopped using the image before any legal judgment was rendered.<ref name="CubaN" />
Ariana Hernández-Reguant addressed the image's copyright status in 2004 in her article ''Copyrighting Che: Art and Authorship under Cuban Late Socialism''. She expressed a skeptical view towards Korda's heirs being able to establish ownership over the image, noting in reference to the lawsuits involving the image, "There was never any official ruling on whether the depiction constituted a violation of copyright." The author goes on to state that: "Korda took the picture while working for a state-run newspaper, his actual property rights would be questionable under both Cuban and international law."<ref>Hernandez-Reguant, Ariana. "Copyrighting Che: Art and Authorship under Cuban Late Socialism". ''Public Culture'' – Volume 16, Number 1, Winter 2004, pp. 1–29, – pp. 4</ref>
{{Quote box | quote="We're not after money, we just don't want him misused. He can be a universal person, but respect the image." | source = — [[Aleida Guevara]], Che's daughter <ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/08/world/americas/08iht-journal.4.7806519.html?pagewanted=all 40 Years After Che Guevara's Death, his Image is a Battleground] by Marc Lacey, ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 8, 2007</ref> | width = 30% | align = left }}
In 2007, law student Sarah Levy also addressed the potential legal status of the image in Cuba. It was her ultimate contention that "in Cuba the copyright protection in Korda's Guevara photograph would have already expired, and despite the claims of ownership from Korda's heirs, the State would now hold any rights associated with the photograph."<ref name="revolution2007">''"A Copyright Revolution: Protecting the Famous Photograph of Che Guevara"'', by Sarah Levy, 13 Law and Business Review of the Americas, Am. 687. Summer of 2007.</ref> In regards to the more commonly disseminated stylized version of the photograph, lawyers say it will be an uphill struggle to deter non-photographic use of such a widely reproduced image, other than in countries like Italy where laws protect image rights.<ref name="commondreams2005" />
Guevara's heirs also believe they have legal justification to prevent the image's "exploitation" or [[slander]]. Guevara's Cuban widow Aleida March stated in 2005 that "We have a plan to deal with the misuse. We can't attack everyone with lances like Don Quixote, but we can try to maintain the ethics of Guevara's legacy."<ref name="commondreams2005" /> In reference to this pronouncement, Guevara's daughter [[Aleida Guevara]] told [[Reuters]], "It will be costly and difficult because each country has different laws, but a limit has to be drawn."<ref name="commondreams2005" /> However, the family has not yet mounted any court challenges, and no determination of legal copyright internationally has been established.
== Further reading and viewing == : {{Main|List of works related to Che Guevara}}
=== Books === * ''Alberto Korda: A Revolutionary Lens'', by Diana Diaz & Mark Sanders, Steidl, 2007, {{ISBN|3-86521-458-4}} * ''Che's Afterlife: The Legacy of an Image'', by Michael Casey, Vintage Books USA, 2009, {{ISBN|0-307-27930-8}} * ''Che Guevara: Revolutionary and Icon'', by Trisha Ziff, Abrams Image, 2006, {{ISBN|0-8109-5718-3}} * ''Che: Images of a Revolutionary'', by Oscar Sola, Pluto Press, 2000, {{ISBN|0-7453-1700-6}} * ''Che: The Photobiography of Che Guevara'', Thunder's Mouth Press, 1998, {{ISBN|1-56025-187-5}} * ''Cuba by Korda'', by Christophe Loviny & Alberto Korda, Ocean Press (AU), 2006, {{ISBN|1-920888-64-0}} * ''Self Portrait Che Guevara'', by Ernesto Guevara & Victor Casaus, Ocean Press (AU), 2004, {{ISBN|1-876175-82-6}}
=== Films === * ''Che Guevara: Kordavision'', 2008 (87 min). Directed by Hector Cruz Sandoval. * ''[[Chevolution]]'', 2008, Produced by Trisha Ziff & Directed by Luis Lopez, Red Envelope Entertainment.<ref>[http://www.cinematical.com/2008/04/27/tribeca-review-chevolution/ Tribeca Review: Chevolution] by Joel Keller, April 27, 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.theenthusiast.com.au/archives/2010/review-chevolution/comment-page-1/#comment-1343 Review: Chevolution] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007070656/http://www.theenthusiast.com.au/archives/2010/review-chevolution/comment-page-1/ |date=2011-10-07 }} by Daniel Zugna, March 16, 2010</ref> * ''Personal Che'', 2008, Directed by Adriana Mariño and Douglas Duarte.<ref>[http://www.personalche.com/ Official Website of "Personal Che"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080914213603/http://www.personalche.com/ |date=2008-09-14 }} directed by Adriana Mariño & Douglas Duarte</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
== External links == {{Portal|Cuba}} {{Commons category}} {{Commons category|Derivative works of Guerrillero Heroico}} * BBC: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7028598.stm Che: The Icon and the Ad], by Stephanie Holmes, October 5, 2007 * CNN Video: [http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/books/05/05/argentina.che.photo/#cnnSTCVideo Examining an Iconic Image] * [https://www.theguardian.com/news/gallery/2007/oct/05/internationalnews1?picture=330898727 Gallery of Pictures] from ''The Guardian'' * [http://www.vam.ac.uk/vastatic/microsites/1541_che/files/85/curators_essay.pdf ''Guerrillero Heroico'': a Brief History] by Trisha Ziff * [http://www.spraypaintstencils.com/a-zlistings/che-guevara-stencil.gif Che Guevara Spray Paint Stencil] * [http://www.chesafterlife.com/images/ ''Che's Afterlife: The Legacy of an Image'' by Michael Casey] – image collection from the book * MSNBC: [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14317481/ Che Guevara, Revolutionary or Chic Icon?] by Tyler Vaughn, August 14, 2006 * ''Washington Post'': [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/23/AR2006092300346_pf.html Che Guevara's Iconic Image Endures] by Martha Irvine, Sept 23 2006

page.title: Inbal Pinto and Avshalom Pollak Dance Company

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Israeli (disambiguation)]] (link changed to [[State of Israel]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} [[File:Inbal Pinto.JPG|thumb|Inbal Pinto, 2008]]
The '''Inbal Pinto and Avshalom Pollak Dance Company''' is an [[State of Israel|Israeli]] [[contemporary dance]] company founded by choreographer [[Inbal Pinto]] and actor [[Avshalom Pollak]], and operates in [[Tel Aviv]], Israel since 1992. Pinto and Pollak are the artistic directors of the company, and are in charge of selecting pieces to represent the company.
==About the Company==
Since 1992, the company has brought many contemporary danceworks to the stage for all sectors of the population. The uniqueness of their creators is seen through every detail in each piece, for example in choreography, [[staging (theatre)|staging]], the selection of [[soundtracks]], [[costume design]], and prop design. The company has 12 regular [[dancers]] and actors, works and conducts shows at the [[Suzanne Dellal Center]], and is often invited to represent Israel at important [[festivals]] and leading cultural events around the globe.
The company's first production was the piece ''A Chance for 100'', which was created by the company and Yossi Pollak-Avshalom Pollak's father.
Apart from contemporary dance performances, the company also performs [[operas]] and musicals. For example, in 2006, they performed the opera ''Armid'' by [[Christoph Willibald Gluck]] in [[Wiesbaden]], Germany, and again at the [[Israeli Opera]]. In 2013, they performed the play ''The Cat that Lived a Million Times'', based on Yoko Sano's book, in Tokyo, Japan, as well as the opera ''The Cunning Little Vixen'' by [[Leos Janacek]] at the Opera house in [[Bergen]], Norway.
Throughout the years Pinto and Pollak cooperated with different artists, among them choreographer Robby Barnett, with whom they created the show ''Rushes'' in 2007 for the American contemporary dance company Pilobolus; the Norwegian company "Kitchen Orchestra", created the soundtracks for ''Trout'', which was performed for the first time in [[Stavanger]], Norway in 2008. Other collaborations include the cooperations with choreographer Talya Bek, who created the works ''Sodad'' in 2009 and ''Empire'' in 2010.
In 2013, illustrators Rony Fahima and Shimrit Alkanti illustrated pictures and animations for the productions of ''The Cunning Little Vixen'' and ''Dust''. Moreover, in 2014, they joined the Japanese Musicians Omitaro Eba, Hirufomi Nakamura, and Mayu Ganto, who had created the music for the show ''Wallflower'' and that Pinto and Pollak had met during their time in Japan working on ''The Cat that Lived a Million Times''. Pinto and Pollak cooperate regularly with French lighting designer Yohan Tiboli.
==Selected work==
{{div col}} * “A chance for a 100” 1994 * “Wrapped” 1998 * “Oyster” 1999 * “Boobies” 2002 * “What Good Would the Moon Be” 2004 * “Armide” 2003 * “Shaker” 2006 * “Armide” 2006 * “Rushes” 2007 * “Hydra” 2007 * “Trout” 2008 * “Toros” 2010 * “Bombyx Mori” 2011 * “Goldfish” 2012 * ”The Cunning Little Vixen” 2013 * ”The Cat that Lived a Million Times” 2013 * "Dust" 2013 * "Wallflower" 2014 * “Wrapped” 2015 (renewed production) * “Slug” 2016 {{div col end}}
==Awards==
{{div col}} *2000 [[Bessie Award]] for "Wrapped" *2000 Israeli Theater Academy award for "Oyster" *2004 The Landau Award for the Arts of the Stage *2007 The Israeli Ministry of Education and Culture award for creation *2011 The Israeli Ministry of Education and Culture awards for Artistic achievements and performance *2014 The Israeli Dance Critics Circle award "Best Dance Show" for "Wallflower" {{div col end}}
==External links== *[http://www.inbalpinto.com/ Inbal Pinto and Avshalom Pollak Dance Company Official Website] *[http://archive.inbalpinto.com/ Inbal Pinto and Avshalom Pollak Dance Company Archives]
[[Category:Contemporary dance]] [[Category:Dance in Israel]]

revision.text:
'''Lion lights''' are flashing lights set up around a perimeter facing outwards; which are used to scare away [[lion]]s.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2013/02/26/tech/richard-turere-lion-lights/index.html Boy scares off lions with flashy invention By Teo Kermeliotis, for CNN]</ref><ref>[http://www.ted.com/talks/richard_turere_a_peace_treaty_with_the_lions.html Richard Turere: My invention that made peace with lions]</ref>
The lion lights were devised by [[Maasai people|Maasai]] Richard Turere to prevent night attacks by lions on his family's [[cattle]] herd, which was in [[Kitengela]] on the unfenced south side of [[Nairobi National Park]], in [[Kenya]]. These types of attacks often lead to the hunting and killing of the lions, which are endangered.
When Richard Turere was 9 he tried kerosene lamps and [[scarecrow]]s but these proved not to work, but he noticed that the lions did not attack when people were present, and he theorised that they were deterred by moving torchlight. Therefore, Turere <ref name="paula">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tnXbRO3CcTQ Lion Li/]</ref> placed LED lights around the perimeter of his family's cow shed, connected them to vehicle indicator flashers, and powered the system from car batteries charged by a solar panel.
The lion attacks ceased and soon neighbours were asking for him to set up similar systems around their farms.<ref name="paula"/> The cattle were also calmer because the lights meant that they could see the land around was safe.
Based on this invention, Turere won a scholarship to [[Brookhouse School]].<ref name="paula"/>
Although originally intended for lions, lion lights may also work for other predators such as [[leopard]]s and [[cheetah]]s.

This is a '''list of gravity hills and magnetic hills''' around the world.
A [[gravity hill]] is a place where a slight downhill slope appears to be an uphill slope due to the layout of the surrounding land, creating the [[optical illusion]] that water flows uphill or that a car left out of gear will roll uphill. Many of these sites have no specific name and are often called just "Gravity Hill", "Magnetic Hill", "Magic Road" or something similar. <!--PLEASE DON'T ADD ANY UNLESS YOU INCLUDE A REFERENCE--> {{TOC right}}
==Australia== <!--PLEASE DON'T ADD ANY UNLESS YOU INCLUDE A REFERENCE--> [[File:Orroroo, Magnetic Hill.JPG|thumb|250px|Magnetic Hill in [[Orroroo, South Australia]]]] [[File:Rua amendoim placa.JPG|right|thumb|250px|Sign for ''Rua do Amendoim'', in [[Belo Horizonte]], Brazil]] *[[Bowen Mountain, New South Wales]]: Bowen Mountain Road, shortly after turnoff from Grose Vale Road. Known as Magnetic Mountain. Hill starts at intersection of Bowen Mountain Road and Westbury Road<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/Richmond-NSW.htm |title=Magnetic Hill - Richmond, NSW |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Moonbi, New South Wales]], near [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]]: "Gravity Hill" near the Moonbi lookout<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/Moonbi-NSW.htm |title=Magnetic Hill - Moonbi, NSW. Australia |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Orroroo, South Australia]]: Magnetic Hill<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/Peterborough-SA.htm |title=Magnetic Hill - Peterborough - South Australia |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/radio/adelaide/programs/afternoons/magnetic-hill/8583982 Magnetic Hill - magnetic forces pulling cars or optical illusion?], [[ABC Adelaide]], 2 June, 2017</ref> *[[Woodend, Victoria|Woodend]], [[Hanging Rock, Victoria]]: Straws Lane<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.news.com.au/travel/australia/hanging-for-a-perfect-picnic-spot/story-e6frfq90-1111113167023 |title=Hanging for a perfect picnic spot |publisher=news.com.au |date= |accessdate=2012-08-18}}</ref>
==Brazil== *[[Belo Horizonte]], [[Minas Gerais]]: Rua Professor Otávio Coelho de Magalhães (official name), popularly known as ''Rua do Amendoim'' ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] for "Peanut Street")<ref>{{cite web |url=http://super.abril.com.br/cultura/a-rua-do-sobe-desce |title=A rua do sobe-desce |language=PT |trans-title=The up and down street |publisher=Editora Abril (Superinteressante) |date=April 1999 |accessdate=2016-05-13}}</ref><ref>[http://www.projetoockham.org/ferramentas_metodo_5.html] {{Pt Icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://worldofsupernatural.blogspot.com/2008/08/mystery-of-ladeira-do-amendoim-slope-of.html |title=The world of the supernatural: The mystery of "Ladeira do Amendoim" (Slope of the Peanut) |publisher=Worldofsupernatural.blogspot.com |date=2008-08-19 |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Exu, Pernambuco|Exu]], [[Pernambuco]]: [[BR-122]], public road connecting Exu to [[Bodocó]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.flatout.com.br/nesta-ladeira-em-pernambuco-os-carros-descem-para-cima/ |title=In this Pernambuco's Road, cars descend upwards |publisher=Flatout |date=2014-04-15 |accessdate=2014-04-15}}</ref>
==Canada== <!--PLEASE DON'T ADD ANY UNLESS YOU INCLUDE A REFERENCE--> [[File:Magnetic Hill Quebec 09.jpg|thumb|250px|Magnetic Hill in [[Chartierville, Quebec]]]] *[[Abbotsford, British Columbia]]: McKee Road just before Ledgeview Golf Course<ref>{{cite web|url=http://userpages.umbc.edu/~frizzell/gravhills.html |title=Gravity Hills |publisher=Userpages.umbc.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-10-09}}</ref> *[[Vernon, British Columbia]]: 5390 Dixon Dam Road<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sharphooks.com/search.aspx?subpage=hotelinfo&hotelid=7238 |title=Magnetic Hill B&B}}</ref> *[[Moncton, New Brunswick]]: [[Magnetic Hill (Moncton)|Magnetic Hill]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.magnetichill.com/english.htm |title=Magnetic Hill |publisher=Magnetic Hill |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903143424/http://www.magnetichill.com/english.htm |archivedate=2011-09-03 |df= }}</ref> *[[Bridgetown, Nova Scotia]]: on Hampton Mountain Road {{convert|2|km|1|abbr=on}} south of Valleyview Provincial Park<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.checkinnovascotia.com/Public/main/event.asp?key=ATT004 |title=Magnetic Hill - Bridgetown |author= |website=Check In Nova Scotia. - Nova Scotia Tourism Information Pages |publisher=Nova Scotia, Dept. of Tourism, Culture & Heritage. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110210433/http://www.checkinnovascotia.com/Public/main/event.asp?key=ATT004 |archivedate=2008-01-10 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Burlington, Ontario]]: King Road, just north of Bayview Park. Stop car at "No Motorized Vehicles" sign, face south.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichill/index.htm |title=Magnetic Hill - Burlington - Ontario |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Caledon, Ontario]]: Escarpment Sideroad approaching Highway 10, stop car at tunnel<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldfortravel.com/2015/01/17/illusionary-magnetic-hills-canada/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513184009/http://www.worldfortravel.com/2015/01/17/illusionary-magnetic-hills-canada/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2016-05-13 |title=Illusionary Magnetic Hills – Canada |accessdate=2016-12-28 }}</ref> *[[Dacre, Ontario]]: Highway 41, near intersection with Highway 132, known as Magnetic Hill<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/Dacre-ON.htm |title=Magnetic Hill - Dacre, Ontario |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Oshawa, Ontario]]: Ritson Road N (north of Raglan Road); just south of tracks, start near large tree on left, you should roll towards tracks.<ref name="Eureka4you.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.provincequebec.com/forests-parc-mountains-quebec/magnetic-hill/ |title=Magnetic Hill - Chartierville, Quebec |publisher=Provincequebec.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160913225806/http://www.provincequebec.com/forests-parc-mountains-quebec/magnetic-hill/ |archive-date=2016-09-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Chartierville, Quebec]]: Magnetic Hill<ref name="Eureka4you.com"/> *[[Notre-Dame-Auxiliatrice-de-Buckland, Quebec]]: Route Saint-Louis (Côte magnétique de Buckland)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buckland.qc.ca/indexFr.asp?numero=91 |title=Attraits |publisher=Municipalité de Notre-Dame-Auxiliatrice-de-Buckland |date= |accessdate=2013-10-26}}</ref>
==China== *[[Gansu]]: a {{convert|200|ft|0|abbr=on|disp=flip}} slope at an angle of 15 degrees in a desert region of [[Sunan Yugur Autonomous County|Sunan County]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.science-frontiers.com/sf125/sf125p10.htm |title=Two Non-falls |publisher=Science-frontiers.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
==Cyprus== *[[Paphos]]: Just after Droushia exit to [[Polis, Cyprus|Polis]] main road.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.paphostravelguide.com/AntiGravity-Road---Optical-Illusion-in-Paphos.php|date=2013-07-05 |title=AntiGravity Road - Optical Illusion in Paphos|accessdate=2013-07-07 |language=cs}}</ref>
==Czech Republic== *Kačerov near [[Zdobnice]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.toulkypocechach.com/anomalie.php |title=Gravitační anomálie u Kačerova |access-date=2016-10-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161102150812/http://www.toulkypocechach.com/anomalie.php |archive-date=2016-11-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Moravská Třebová]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ba4BpZHyzhg |title=Gravity Hill - Moravská Třebová |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2008-08-05 |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
==Dominican Republic== *[[Polo, Dominican Republic|Polo]]: El Polo Magnético ("The Magnetic Pole")<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/Cabral-DR.htm |title=Magnetic Pole - Cabral, Barahona. Dominican Republic |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
==Germany== *On the L3053 between [[Butzbach]] and [[Hausen-Oes]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goede-stiftung.org/experimente/Bericht-Natuerliche-Gravitationsanomalien-TJ1.pdf |title=Bericht über Natürliche Gravitationsanomalie |publisher=goede-stiftung.org}}</ref>
==Greece== *At the road to [[Leivithra]], [[Pieria (regional unit)|Pieria]]. [https://www.pieria.tv/μαγνητικο-πεδιο-λειβηθρα-ανατολικου Μαγνητικό Πεδίο Λειβήθρων]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pieria.tv/μαγνητικο-πεδιο-λειβηθρα-ανατολικου|title=Μαγνητικο πεδιο Λειβήθρων|last=|first=|date=|website=pieria.tv|publisher=pieria.tv|access-date=}}</ref>
==Guatemala== *Paso Misterioso, on the road from Cocales, [[Suchitepéquez Department|Suchitepéquez]] to [[San Lucas Tolimán]], [[Sololá]], about {{convert|130|km|0|abbr=on}} from the [[Guatemala City|capital city]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.viajeros.com/diarios/guatemala/subida-o-bajada |title=Subida o Bajada? |publisher=Viajeros.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.clubbyb.com/index.php?id=125 |title=Sabias Que?... El paso misterioso |publisher=Clubbyb.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708165419/http://www.clubbyb.com/index.php?id=125 |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }}</ref>

Loma Alta Dr.<ref>[http://hauntedlosangeles.blogspot.com/2013/03/los-angeles-gravity-hill.html?m=1* Haunted Los Angeles]</ref> *[[Rohnert Park]] (in [[Sonoma County, California|Sonoma County]]): From [[U.S. Route 101|US 101 Freeway]], take Rohnert Park Expressway east to Petaluma Hill Road, Petaluma Hill Road south to Roberts Road, Roberts Road east to Lichau Road. Vehicles stop in the tunnel that the West Kentucky Parkway bridge creates and the vehicle will roll all the way to the end of the road at the stop sign <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/Princeton-KY.htm |title=Gravity Hill – Princeton, Kentucky |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date=1941-02-15 |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>

===Michigan=== *[[Blaine Township, Michigan|Blaine Township]] (near [[Arcadia Township, Manistee County, Michigan|Arcadia]]): Putney Road south of its intersection with Joyfield Road<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/Arcadia-MI.htm |title=Gravity Hill – Arcadia, Michigan |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date=1994-11-27 |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Rose City, Michigan|Rose City]]: at the end of Reasner Road, past Heath Road<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/RoseCity-MI.htm |title=Magnetic Hill – Rose City, Michigan |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
===Minnesota=== 330th St and 660th Ave., Watkins <ref>[http://www.hauntedplaces.org/item/660th-ave-gravity-hill/ hauntedplaces: 660th ave gravity hill]</ref>
===Mississippi=== *[[Burnsville, Mississippi|Burnsville]]<ref>[http://www.onlyinyourstate.com/mississippi/gravity-hill-ms/ This Strange Phenomenon In Mississippi Is Too Weird For Words]</ref>
===Missouri=== *[[Freeman, Missouri|Freeman]]: southwest of town near the [[Kansas]] border at the intersection of State Highway D and East 299th Street. Just outside [[Louisburg, Kansas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ghosttraveller.com/missouri.htm |title=Missouri |publisher=Ghosttraveller |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
===Montana=== *[[Columbia Falls, Montana|Columbia Falls]]: The Montana Vortex<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.montanavortex.com/ |title=The Montana Vortex and House of Mystery |publisher=montanavortex.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-25}}</ref>
===New Jersey=== *[[Franklin Lakes, New Jersey|Franklin Lakes]]: Ewing Avenue exit off [[New Jersey Route 208|Rte. 208]] South<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tips/getAttraction.php?tip_AttractionNo==874 |title=Franklin Lakes, New Jersey – Gravity-Defying Exit Ramp |publisher=Roadsideamerica.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Jackson Township, New Jersey|Jackson]]: New Prospect Road<ref>[https://archive.is/20130126162032/http://www.jacksonnjonline.com/2011/09/27/uncovering-gravity-hill-in-jackson-township-nj/27726/ Jackson Family and Community Magazine -> : Uncovering Gravity Hill In Jackson Township, NJ]</ref>
===North Carolina=== *[[Boone, North Carolina|Boone]]: Mystery Hill<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mysteryhill-nc.com |title=Mystery Hill |publisher=Mysteryhill-nc.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Richfield, North Carolina|Richfield]]: Gravity Hill on Richfield Rd. Local legends suggest paranormal causes for phenomenon.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.onlyinyourstate.com/north-carolina/gravity-hill-nc/ |title=This Strange Phenomenon In A North Carolina Town Is Too Weird For Words |publisher=OnlyInYourState.com |accessdate=2016-01-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.catawbapioneer.com/paranormal-profile-gravity-hill/ |title=Paranormal Profile: Gravity Hill |publisher=Pioneer: The Student Newspaper of Catawba College |accessdate=2016-01-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wral.com/lifestyles/travel/video/14764668/ |title=Gravity Hill defies physics |publisher=WRAL |accessdate=2016-01-27}}</ref>
===Ohio=== *[[Kirtland Hills, Ohio|Kirtland Hills]]: King Memorial Road<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/snap7901/id37.htm Gravity Hill]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Oklahoma=== *[[Bartlesville, Oklahoma|Bartlesville]]: Gap Road<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.strangeusa.com/Viewlocation.aspx?id=7827 |title=Haunt in Haunted Hill Bartlesville, Ok 74006 Bartlesville, OKLAHOMA Washington Haunt |publisher=Strangeusa.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-09}}</ref> *[[Springer, Oklahoma|Springer]]: Near [[Ardmore, Oklahoma|Ardmore]], on Pitt Road.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onlyinyourstate.com/oklahoma/gravity-hill-ok |title=This Strange Phenomena in Oklahoma is Too Weird for Words |publisher=OnlyInYourState.com| date=|accessdate=2016-01-27}}</ref>
===Oregon=== *[[Gold Hill, Oregon|Gold Hill]]: the [[Oregon Vortex]]<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.oregonvortex.com/ |title=The Oregon Vortex and location of the House of Mystery |publisher=Oregonvortex.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
===Pennsylvania=== *Near [[Lewisberry, Pennsylvania|Lewisberry]], [[York County, Pennsylvania|York County]], on Pleasantview Road (also rendered Pleasant View Road) at [[Pennsylvania Route 177|State Route 177]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/Harrisburg-PA.htm |title=Gravity Hill - Harrisburg - Pennsylvania |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[New Paris, Pennsylvania|New Paris]]: Gravity Hill Road (two gravity hills in this area)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/NewParis-PA.htm |title=Gravity Hill - New Paris -Pennsylvania |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bedfordcounty.net/gravityhill/index.htm |title=GRAVITY HILL, Pennsylvania Phenomenon |publisher=Bedfordcounty.net |date=2010-05-04 |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *Near [[Uniontown, Pennsylvania|Uniontown]]: [[Laurel Caverns]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tips/getAttraction.php?tip_AttractionNo==3303 |title=Hopwood, Pennsylvania - Laurel Caverns - Cave Mini Golf |publisher=Roadsideamerica.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
===South Dakota=== *[[Rapid City, South Dakota|Rapid City]]: [[Cosmos Mystery Area]], {{convert|16|mi}} south of Rapid City on [[U.S. Route 16|Hwy 16]], {{convert|6|mi|0}} from [[Mount Rushmore]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cosmosmysteryarea.com/ |title=Cosmos Mystery Area Home |publisher=Cosmosmysteryarea.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
===Texas=== *[[El Paso, Texas|El Paso]]: Thunderbird Drive facing south<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tips/getAttraction.php?tip_AttractionNo==1298 |title=San Antonio, Texas – Ghostly Gravity Hill |publisher=Roadsideamerica.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[San Antonio]]: Just east of the [[San Antonio Missions National Historical Park]] at the railway crossing at Villamain Road and Shane Road<ref>[http://www.snopes.com/horrors/ghosts/handprint.asp Helping Hands], [[Snopes.com]] (retrieved 21 August 2010)</ref>
===Utah=== *[[Salt Lake City]]: A few blocks northeast of the [[Utah State Capitol|Capitol]] building in Salt Lake City. A small road (Bonneville Boulevard) loops around a park called [[Memory Grove (Salt Lake City)|Memory Grove]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tips/getAttraction.php?tip_AttractionNo==1833 |title=Salt Lake City, Utah – Gravity Hill |publisher=Roadsideamerica.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
===Virginia=== *[[Danville, Virginia|Danville]]: Berry Hill Rd (VA 863/US 311) and Oak Hill Rd (VA 862)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onlyinyourstate.com/virginia/strange-phenomenon-va/ |title=This Strange Phenomenon In Virginia Is Too Weird For Words|publisher=onlyinyourstate.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-21}}</ref>
===Washington=== *[[Prosser, Washington|Prosser]]: Near a small farm on North Crosby Road, approximately {{convert|10|mi|0}} northeast of Prosser. Set vehicle into neutral at the word "start" that is written across the surface of the road.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.strangeusa.com/ViewLocation.aspx?locationid=10528 |title=Haunt in Whitstran Prosser, Wa 99350 Prosser, WASHINGTON Benton Haunt |publisher=Strangeusa.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>
===Wisconsin=== *[[Shullsburg, Wisconsin|Shullsburg]]: Judgement Street, just after Rennick Road<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eureka4you.com/magnetichillworldwide/Shullsburg-WI.htm |title=Gravity Hill – Shullsburg, Wisconsin |publisher=Eureka4you.com |date=1994-07-18 |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unexplainedresearch.com/files_anomalies/gravity_hill.html |title=Gravity Hill Road |publisher=Unexplained Research |date=2004-09-28 |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Stockbridge, Wisconsin|Stockbridge]]: Joe Road, {{convert|3|mi|0|abbr=on}} south of Stockbridge west off [[Wisconsin Highway 55|STH 55]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unexplainedresearch.com/files_anomalies/joe_road.html |title=Joe Road |publisher=Unexplained Research |date=2004-09-28 |accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> *[[Weyerhaeuser, Wisconsin|Weyerhaeuser]]: County Highway W, {{convert|2|mi|0|abbr=on}} North of Old 14
===Wyoming=== *[[Casper, Wyoming|Casper]]: Garden Creek Road, near the entrance to Rotary Park, when going toward Casper Mountain Road<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.trib.com/news/local/answer-girl-the-seven-or-so-wonders/article_b9dc1d7b-f868-594d-aa3e-7b994958a6c1.html |title=Answer Girl: The Seven... or so... Wonders |publisher=Casper Star Tribune |date=2008-06-19 |accessdate=2015-07-28}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = <!-- Magda Sawon --> | other_names = <!--Magdalena Sawon--> | residence = [[New York, NY]] | occupation = Gallery owner and director | known_for = Founding [[Postmasters Gallery]] }} '''Magda Sawon''' is a [[Contemporary art gallery|contemporary art gallerist]] and art world figure who founded and owns New York's [[Postmasters Gallery]] (with her husband Tamas Banovich), a gallery for young and established contemporary artists, especially those working in new media, in the [[Tribeca]] neighborhood of New York City. The gallery is considered to be one of the "leading experimental galleries" in New York City.<ref name=viveros-faune>{{cite news|last=Viveros-Faune|first=Christian|title=How Uptown Money Kills Downtown Art|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2013-02-06/art/uptown-money-kills-downtown-art/3/|accessdate=3 April 2014|newspaper=The Village Voice|date=February 6, 2013}}</ref>
== Early career == Magdalena Sawon came to Manhattan from [[Poland]] in 1981, having studied art history with an emphasis in [[Japonism]] in Warsaw, earning a Master's degree.<ref name="Fensterstock2013">{{cite book|author=Ann Fensterstock|title=Art on the Block: Tracking the New York Art World from SoHo to the Bowery, Bushwick and Beyond|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0X83AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA271|date=17 September 2013|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-1-137-27849-4|pages=271–}}</ref> After a job in a shoe store, and emboldened by a class she took at the [[New School]] taught by Estelle Schwartz, she struck out with partner Tamas Banovich, opening an art gallery in the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]] on Avenue A between 4th and 5th Streets<ref name=interview>{{cite web|last=Lanfranco|first=Katerina|title=tArt roundtable discussion with Magda Sawon at Postmasters Gallery|url=http://tartblog.wordpress.com/2012/11/29/tart-roundtable-discussion-with-magda-sawon-postmasters-gallery/|accessdate=30 March 2014}}</ref> in December 1984.<ref name="gallery website">{{cite web|title=Postmasters Gallery|url=http://www.postmastersart.com/gallery_window.html|accessdate=30 March 2014}}</ref> The name of the gallery referenced being "post" the European masters, alludes to Postmodernism, and also points to an early interest in [[mail art]] and its distribution by the postal service.<ref name="Fensterstock2013" />
In 1988, Sawon and Banovich moved Postmasters Gallery to a [[Soho]] loft space at Greene and Spring Streets.<ref name=interview /><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Roberta|title=ART VIEW; The Gallery Is the Message|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/04/arts/art-view-the-gallery-is-the-message.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 4, 1992}}</ref> Later, the gallery was relocated to Chelsea (1998)<ref>{{cite book|last=Friend|first=David|title=Watching the World Change: The Stories Behind the Images of 9/11|date=2011|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=9781429933155|page=251|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D3YQIY1ShFYC&lpg=PA251&dq=%22Magda%20Sawon%22&pg=PA251#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> and Tribeca in October 2013.<ref name="gallery website" /> Sawon lived in the East Village and Chelsea prior to her move to Soho.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Claire|title=Turning the High Line Into the High Life|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/18/realestate/18cover.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 18, 2005}}</ref> In 2002, Sawon sold a work from her gallery (by artists [[Jennifer & Kevin McCoy|Jennifer and Kevin McCoy]]) to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], which she described as a highlight of her career.<ref>{{cite web|last=Joseph-Hunter|first=Galen|title=Electronic Arts Intermix - Conversation with Magda Sawon|url=http://www.eai.org/resourceguide/collection/computer/interview_sawon.html|accessdate=30 March 2014}}</ref>
==Other contributions== In addition to her directorial and curatorial activities at Postmasters Gallery, Sawon was elected to the board of [[Rhizome (organization)|Rhizome]] in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|title=Press:Rhizome.org Elects Magdalena Sawon to Board of Directors|url=http://rhizome.org/discuss/2409/|accessdate=30 March 2014}}</ref> She also is a founding member of [http://www.seven-miami.com/ SEVEN] art fair,<ref name=interview /> started in 2010.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.crumbweb.org/getInterviewDetail.php?id=35&op=3 CRUMBS Interview with Magda Sawon and Tamas Banovich]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sawon, Magda}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Business of visual arts]] [[Category:American art dealers]] [[Category:Polish emigrants to the United States]]

The '''Modistae''' ([[Latin]] for "'''Modists'''"), also known as the '''speculative grammarians''', were the members of a school of [[grammar]]ian philosophy known as '''Modism''' or '''speculative grammar''', active in northern [[Kingdom of France|France]], [[Holy Roman Empire|Germany]], [[Kingdom of England|England]], and [[Kingdom of Denmark|Denmark]] in the 13th and 14th centuries. Their influence was felt much less in the southern part of Europe, where the somewhat opposing tradition of the so-called "pedagogical grammar" never lost its preponderance. {{TOC limit|2}}
==History<!--'Ralph of Beauvais', 'Speculative grammarians', and 'Thomas of Erfurt' redirect here-->== [[William of Conches]], [[Peter Helias]], and '''Ralph of Beauvais'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA-->, also referred to as '''speculative grammarians'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA--> predate the Modist movement proper.
The Modist philosophy was first developed by [[Martin of Dacia]] (died 1304) and his colleagues in the mid-13th century, though it would rise to prominence only after its systematization by '''Thomas of Erfurt'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA--> decades later, in his treatise ''De modis significandi seu grammatica speculativa'', probably written in the first decade of the 14th century. Until the early twentieth-century this work was assumed to have been authored by [[John Duns Scotus]]. Widely reproduced and commented upon in the [[Middle Ages]], it remains the most complete textbook of Modist speculative grammar. The mistaken authorship arose out of the natural affinity of Erfurt's speculative grammar with Scotus's metaphysics.
==Theory of modes== The philosophy of the Modistae, as indicated by their name, was based on a theory of 'modes' of meaning in language which was tripartite: modes of being (''modi essendi''), modes of understanding (''modi intelligendi''), and modes of signifying (''modi significandi''). To the Modistae, the various [[parts of speech]] were viewed as representing [[reality]] in terms of these modes. The ''modi essendi'' are objectively existent qualities in an object of understanding, the ''modi intelligendi'' the understanding's means of representing the ''modi essendi'', and the ''modi significandi'' grammar's means of representing the ''modi intelligendi'' in language. This corresponds to Aristotle's tripartite semantic theory of ''words'' representing ''concepts'' which represent ''objects''.
Opposing [[nominalism]], they assumed that the analysis of the [[grammar]] of ordinary language was the key to [[metaphysics]]. For the Modistae, grammatical forms, the ''modi significandi'' of verbs, nouns, and adjectives, comprise the deep [[ontological]] structure of language, which objectively reflects reality. Their work predicted the concept of [[universal grammar]], suggesting that universal grammatical rules may be extracted from all living languages. [[Roger Bacon]] may have given the movement inspiration with his observation that all languages are built upon a common grammar, a shared foundation of ontologically anchored linguistic structures. He argued grammar is substantially the same in all languages, even though it may undergo accidental variations between languages.
==Influences== There are parallels between speculative grammar and [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]], a fact that was picked up early on by [[Martin Heidegger]], who wrote his first book, ''Die Kategorien-und Bedeutungslehre des Duns Scotus'', on Thomas of Erfurt's treatise (at that time still mistakenly attributed to Duns Scotus).
==Modists== *[[Martin of Dacia]], ''De modis significandi'' (after 1255) *[[Boetius of Dacia]], ''De modis significandi sive Quaestiones super Priscianum majorem'' (c. 1270) * [[John of Dacia]], ''[[Summa Grammatica (John of Dacia)|Summa Grammatica]]'' (c. 1280) * [[Simonis of Dacia]], ''Domus gramaticae'' (1255-1270) *[[Radulphus Brito]], ''Quaestiones super Priscianum minore'' (c. 1300) *[[Thomas of Erfurt]], ''Tractatus de modis significandi seu grammatica speculativa'' (before 1310) *[[Siger of Courtrai]], ''Summa modorum significandi'' (1320).
==See also== *[[Roger Bacon]]'s ''[[Summa Grammatica]]'' *[[Dante]]'s ''[[De vulgari eloquentia]]'' *[[philosophical language]]
==References==
===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}}
===Bibliography===
====Primary sources==== * Radulphus Brito, ''Quaestiones super Priscianum minore'', ed. by Jan Pingorg and K. W. Enders, Stuttgart-Bad Cannstatt: Frommann-Holzboog, 1980. * Thomas of Erfurt, ''Grammatica speculativa'', translated by G.L. Bursill-Hall, London: Longmans, 1972. * Siger of Courtrai, ''Summa modorum significandi; Sophismata'' ed. by Jan Pinborg, Philadelphia: John Benjamins, 1977. * Corpus Philosophorum Danicorum Medii Aevi: ** I,1-2: Johannis Daci Opera, 1955 ** II: Martini de Dacia Opera, 1961 ** III: Simonis Daci Opera, 1963 ** IV: Boethii Daci Modi significandi, 1969.
====Secondary sources==== * Bursill-Hall, G. L. ''Speculative Grammars of the Middle Ages: The Doctrine of the partes orationis of the Modistae'', Approaches to Semantics, 11, Mouton: The Hague, 1971. * Fredborg, Karin Margareta. ''Universal Grammar According to Some 12th-Century Grammarians'', in Studies in Medieval Linguistic Thought, ed. Konrad Koerner et al., Historiographia Linguistica, VII.1/2, John Benjamins, Amsterdam, 1980, 69-84. * Fredborg, Karin Margareta. ''Speculative Grammar'', in A History of Twelfth-Century Philosophy, ed. Peter Dronke, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1988, 177-195. * Kelly, Louis G. ''The Mirror of Gammar. Theology, Philosophy, and the Modistae'', Philadelphia : J. Benjamins, 2002. * Marmo, Costantino. ''A Pragmatic Approach to Language in Modism'', in ''Sprachtheorien in Spätantike und Mittelalter'', ed. Sten Ebbesen, Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag, 1995, 169-183. * Pinborg, Jan. ''Speculative Grammar'', in ''The Cambridge History of Later Medieval Philosophy'', Norman Kretzmann, Anthony Kenny, and Jan Pinborg (eds.), Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1982, 254–69. * Pinborg, Jan. ''Logik und Semantik im Mittelalter. Ein Uberblick'', Stuttgart-Bad Cannstatt: Frommann-Holzboog, 1972. * Pinborg, Jan. ''Radulphus Brito’s sophism on second intentions'', Vivarium, 13, 1975, 119–152, * Rosier, Irène. ''La grammaire spéculative des Modistes'', Lille: Presses universitaires de Lille, 1983.
==External links== *{{cite SEP |url-id=erfurt |title=Thomas of Erfurt |last=Zupko |first=Jack}}
